abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that Oblast and
            municipal (local) authorities were left with post-1991
            responsibilities for social infrastructure, often with
            limited or nonexistent resources for its maintenance and
            development. The number of sectors included in the Russian
            Federation Community Social Infrastructure Project (CSIP)
            made it more difficult to supervise, problematical in terms
            of support both by the Bank (involved in several sectors,
            but owned by none) and the Federal government, and less
            reliable as a vehicle to effect policy change. The improved
            levels of architecture, design, and materials brought by the
            project yielded benefits in terms of lower maintenance
            costs, better functionality, and a demonstration effect in
            terms of non-Bank financed work funded by the oblasts. The
            CSIP achieved significant benefits in the pilot regions, and
            made substantial efforts to disseminate the lessons from
            these efforts, but achieved little-except in neighboring
            oblasts. Initial design of the project institutional reform
            agenda has to be more detailed in assessing the current
            framework and be realistic in forecasting the direction of
            expected changes, taking into account also political economy
            considerations. CSIP went through several reorganizations of
            the federal implementing agency (Ministry of Nationalities)
            and two changes of administrations in Novosibirsk oblast.
            Luckily, stability of executing agencies (Central and
            regional Central Project Implementation Units) ensured
            continuity and eventual satisfactory implementation of the
            project. CSIP was one of the earlier projects the Russian
            portfolio and implementation difficulties were
            underestimated in the project design. This aspect of project
            implementation in Russia is much better understood now both
            by the Bank and by the Government counterparts and
            appropriate actions have been agreed through CPPR process,
            guidelines for project preparation, and regular practice of
            project preparation review.
